Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to broaden participation of women and underrepresented groups in visualization. The PI proposes to establish an annual two-day workshop and other activities designed to increase the participation of women and underrepresented groups in visualization. Visualization plays a significant role in the exploration and understanding of data across all disciplines with a universal goal: gaining insight into the complex relationships that exist within the data. The need to diversify a field with such far reaching influences by providing career mentoring advice, overviews of past accomplishments, and future research directions in visualization is important. The proposed workshops advances the NSF mission by informing, inspiring and encouraging diverse participants to engage in the multidisciplinary dynamics of visualization and scientific research.

The first supported workshop was held in 2014 at Clemson University in South Carolina. The second workshop will be held in 2016. About 20 participants at the undergraduate, graduate, post-graduate, and early career faculty level will be invited to participate in the workshop. The workshop will be organized as a series of presentations, panels with networking opportunities, and mentoring activities. To encourage collaborations, participants will present their work and explore the work of others during a poster session. Participants will be recruited via a number of different venues including, but not limited to: The Anita Borge Institute/Grace Hopper listserv, association listservs (CRA, CRA-W, CDC, AAPHDCS, Hispanics in Computing, and Women in Machine Learning), Broadening Participation Communities (A4RC, EL Alliance) and discipline-specific mailing lists (IEEE-Vis). Undergraduates will be recruited by on-campus organizations (Women in Science and Engineering and The Charles H. Houston Center). The inclusion of undergraduates will ensure the level of interest in visualization spans across academic and professional domains. Outcomes of the workshops will be assessed by surveying participants at the start and at the end of the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop hosted 96 participants, diverse in background (academic and professional status), and visualization interests over the workshop’s funding cycle. Targeted participants included women and members of underrepresented groups as well as participants from underrepresented disciplines in data visualization and students from minority serving institutions. Forty-four percent of the participants were female, and 56% male. Self-reported race/ethnicity by participants revealed 30% of the participants were African American, 9% Hispanic, 2% Native Hawaiian, 41% Caucasian, 2% Asian Indian, 2%Vietnamese-American, 7% Asian, 5% Mideastern and 2% reported unknown ethnicity. Nineteen percent of the participants were from historically black colleges and universities (HBCUs), 5% from minority serving universities (MSIs) and 77% were from predominantly white institutions (PWIs). Data visualization skills are needed and desired at all levels of scholarship.  The workshop included undergraduates, graduate students, post-docs, faculty members, research scientists, members from education outreach community, K-16 instructors, and self-funded participation from K-12 participants (high school juniors, seniors and instructors), and visualization artists. The workshop provided career mentoring advice from experts in the field, hands-on training, and research directions in visualization. The workshop also provided mentoring, networking and professional development activities. Respected and leading members from the visualization community in academia and industry with mentoring experience and/or from an underrepresented group were invited to participate in the workshop as speakers and/or panelists. In 2016 selected participants from BPViz14 were invited to serve as panelists in BPViz’16. The panel also consisted of a recent graduate and alumni of the REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Collaborative Data Visualization Applications. Workshop training included: an introduction to ParaView, interactive demonstrations using oculus rift, digital choreography featuring Virtual Director/Partiview software, a hands-on Sci –Vis workshop and The Internet of Things: sensing for visualization.  In addition to training on visualization software, the workshop served as a medium for sharing of ideas and as a source for constructive feedback. The highlight of the workshop is the visualization showcase where participants share their work in progress either during the poster session or during a lightning talk.

 

Participant feedback was positive and supportive. Findings revealed overall, participants liked the workshop, rated all of the sessions of the workshop highly and intended to use the knowledge gained from the workshop at their institutions. Participants recommended offering the workshop regularly would be helpful. The two day workshops were packed with value able information and training. Recommendations from participants include: the workshops could benefit from adding a third day and/or creating more concurrent sessions that allow for training to match multiple-skill-levels.

 

The workshops focused on helping women and members of underrepresented groups at the undergraduate, graduate, post-graduate  and early career faculty level become interested in and knowledgeable about visualization paradigms and fostered collaborations among participants. The workshop served as a medium for initiating conversations about current visualization research challenges and the role participants play in contributing to and developing solutions to these challenges. The workshop facilitated mentoring from experts in the field who are themselves members of underrepresented group(s) and by sharing their experience in the field encouraged participants to consider visualization as a research path.

Cumulatively, a number of venues were utilized to build interest in and market the workshop which include: five presentations, three invited talks (including a keynote talk), three conference presentations, and two publications. An additional publication manuscript is in preparation. Newsletters, The Viz Vignette, were created and disseminated at talks, conferences, and presentations to showcase highlights from each workshop.

After two successful implementations of the workshop and the building of a community of persons with interest in broadening participation in visualization, BPViz has been accepted into the workshop program at IEEE Vis workshop program. BPViz 2017 will be hosted in conjunction with IEEE Vis 2017, in October. The workshop’s continued success is one of the first steps towards diversifying a field with far reaching influences that fosters opportunities for collaboration and knowledge discovery.

Numerous venues were utilized for dissemination of workshop events and outcomes. The most recent include:

 International High Performance Computing Summer School, Ljubljana, Slovenia, June 2016.

Byrd, Vetria (2016). The 9th International Symposium on Visual Information Communication and Interaction (VINCI 2016). Facilitating Visualization Capacity Building, Panel, VINCI’16, Dallas, TX, September 24-26, 2016.

Conferences

Panel: Visualization Research. Alberto Roca. Panelist: Vetria Byrd, Ron Metoyer, Tapia 2016 Conference

Missouri S&T, Research Technology and Development Conference, Rolla, MO, September 12-13, 2016

IEEE 2016 RESPECT: Research on Equity and Sustained Participation in Engineering, Computing, and Technology Conference; Lightening Talk.
